Key Arguments: The bill is seen as an attack on freedom of speech and democratic values.
It creates an unfair division between politicians, journalists, and educators versus ordinary citizens in terms of freedom of expression.
Excessive fines will lead to overly restrictive digital services, stifling dialogue and debate.
Broad definitions of misinformation and disinformation threaten open discussions.
The bill could favor larger digital services over smaller competitors, undermining fair market competition.
Extraterritorial application burdens foreign entities and isolates Australia from the global internet community.
The bill infringes on the implied constitutional freedom of political communication.
It poses threats to digital platform providers and ordinary citizens, reminiscent of oppressive regimes.
The News Media Bargaining Code limits the capacity to address misinformation effectively.
Notable Quotes: This bill is a direct attack on our freedom of speech and an infringement on the democratic values that our nation holds dear.

The government's assumption that it can determine what is true without considering the experiences and viewpoints of ordinary Australians diminishes the diversity of perspectives essential for informed decision-making.
This style of governance is reminiscent of oppressive regimes and undermines the principles of mateship and diversity that Australia holds dear.
